Clone Drone in the Danger Zone catapults players into an exhilarating and unique experience that seamlessly blends fast-paced combat, humor, and creative mechanics. The game's premise of battling through waves of robots in deadly arenas is not only entertaining but executed with a level of polish that captivates players from the get-go.

The combat mechanics are a shining beacon of the game's excellence. The swordplay feels fluid, and the ability to slice and dice through enemies with precision is immensely satisfying. The inclusion of various weapons, upgrades, and abilities ensures that each playthrough is a dynamic and strategic endeavor, making the combat both accessible and deep.

The game's sense of humor is a delightful touch. The witty commentary and quirky interactions contribute to a lighthearted atmosphere, making the intense battles feel even more enjoyable. The developers' creativity shines through in both the design of the enemies and the humorous dialogue, creating a gaming experience that is as amusing as it is engaging.

Clone Drone's innovation extends to its Twitch integration, allowing streamers and their audiences to directly influence the gameplay. This interaction not only enhances the entertainment value but also fosters a sense of community involvement that is rare in the gaming world.

However, the glaring downside to Clone Drone in the Danger Zone lies in its server issues. The occasional lag spikes and connectivity problems can disrupt the otherwise seamless experience, leading to frustrating moments during critical gameplay. This issue, while not pervasive, does detract from the overall enjoyment, especially in the more intense stages where split-second decisions are crucial.

Despite the server-related drawbacks, Clone Drone in the Danger Zone remains a stellar title that excels in its genre. The combination of engaging combat, humorous elements, and innovative features makes it a standout experience. With a bit of improvement on the server stability front, this game could easily reach even greater heights and solidify its place as a beloved indie gem.

The game's fun on its own, but the multiplayer aspect is very disappointing.

Is has no steamworks support nor P2P support. 
All servers are hosted publicly, no dedicated servers and for private games you have to join using a code so no inviting and joining directly through steam.
Private games are really fun but public games take a very long time to start since after every round you have to effectively rejoin the server, which depending on your region may have latency issues as well.

For endless mode, difficulty doesn't seem to increase past a certain point. After we had all upgrades unlocked it was a slog to keep going since it was a constant repeat of the same maps, the same enemies.

For Last Bot Standing, private servers have a glaring lack of customization. You have a set amount of credits (4) you can spend and that's it, you can't increase/decrease initial credits nor can you lock certain upgrades, which would otherwise allow for some very interesting matches.

Otherwise, a really fun game to play with friends, but I wouldn't recommend it unless it's on sale. May amend my review if they ever add steamworks support since that's my biggest qualm with the game.

Clone Drone is super weird and unique game that I spent more time on than I expected to. Don't let the visuals fool you though, this is a very difficult game.

Visually this game looks very simple. Everything is made of blocks. All the enemies in this game have different designs and different colours to make them easy to tell apart and to tell how dangerous they are. Music is also pretty good. All characters in this game that can speak have the generic robot voices that you would assume they might have.

The gameplay is what you're really here for. The gameplay focuses almost entirely on the combat and the combat is quite unique compared to other games. There are no health bars in this game. You die whenever your body takes too much damage. These can evolve losing both your legs, losing your right arm, because then you can't hold weapons, your torso taking too much damage, or your head taking too much damage. Your strikes are directional, you can either strike left, right , or straight down. Your weapon will cut wherever it lands in that direction, so its possible to cut enemies in halve, or cut off their arm, or their leg. This game also has a lot of content. There's the single player endless mode and a co-op endless mode, there are single player challenges and co-op challenges, there's a free for all pvp mode, private duels, twitch mode for streamers, and a campaign. The first two chapters of the campaign is pretty simple, it's chapter three where the campaign gets insane, it's a lot of fun. There's also a workshop for this game, so there is always more content if need it. A warning though for this game is that it's quite difficult. Some flaws with this game is that the co-op challenges drag on for way too long and the UI sometimes glitches and needs to be reloaded.

The game does have a story, but it's very simple and only serves as a set up for the game and is there for the purpose of the campaign mode. The humour will work for some people,but will annoy others. Personally I think its fine.

In conclusion, you can get a good amount of hours out of this game and the pvp mode is pretty competitive. Combat is unique and different. I would say though to buy this on sale just to be safe.

Overall a VERY fun game would recommend.

Clone Drone in the Danger Zone is a combat-focused horde fighting game. You play as a human converted into a robot body and are pitted against hundreds of various enemies in a practically endless arena. Personally, I love this game.

One thing I look for in a combat-focused game is a deep and intricate combat system. At first, this game's combat system seems pretty simple. Sword hit enemy = dead. Easy, right? Then you learn about things like blocking, parrying, armour-bypassing, the difference between side strikes against different enemies, and suddenly it becomes a lot more complicated. Then you realise there are four (maybe five) weapons that CAN be used in isolation, but can also be combined with your other weapons, and all of a sudden the combat system feels a lot more complicated. There's a lot to learn, and while the skill floor is very low (since anyone can grasp the basics of this game's sword combat, it's really simple), the skill ceiling is incredibly high. What's even better is that they didn't need to include any combo system in the game, making it much less daunting to players new to combat systems.

Another important thing in combat-focused games is the enemies. Clone Drone in the Danger Zone has a whole host of enemy types, each stronger than the last and carrying various weapons. What makes the enemies even more fun to fight is that each robot sports its own AI. The lower tier ones just run at you in a straight line. However, the higher tier ones move almost like actual players, requiring a great amount of skill to overcome.

Onto the graphics. It takes a voxel-based approach since slicing and dicing robots is a big part of the game. It's quite satisfying to melt away a robot by slamming a hammer into them, or cut up a robot with a laser sword. The colours can be a tad bit flat at times, but the game still looks amazing.

The music is also stellar. There are a whole host of tracks that convey different emotions. From intense combat, to fear, to heroism, etc. Although, it can get a bit repetitive at one point, especially the arena music that plays constantly throughout the survival mode and in parts of the campaign mode.

Finally, there's the story. Clone Drone in the Danger Zone has a campaign mode comprised of five chapters. The story itself is quite exciting, and has its fair share of twists and turns. However, I felt as if it did end on a bit of a "not sure" note. It absolutely didn't have a bad ending, but the ending didn't feel extremely satisfying. It felt a bit rushed. Although, it didn't detract too much from the overall story.

In the end, Clone Drone in the Danger Zone is a fantastic horde-based fighting game with a lot of depth and fun to be had. Whether you like slicing enemies, taking them from afar, feeling like a hero, or designing your own levels, there's always classic fun to be had in the robot arena.

A game of pure skill. I am actually not the best at hand eye coordination but still, every death feels fair. Simple game loop will never get old. Lots of stuff to do in single player which is a + for me. It has the old skool feel of, a game that was designed to be fully finished with out extra stuff. And lots to do with the basic interactions in the game. It has a great level editor which seems to allow for scripted events. Some very good levels out there. Story is nice. Challenge modes are great. Endless mode is there to live out whatever over powered set of upgrades you dream of trying together, but only if you are skilled enough the clear enough endless levels to get them all.  (my top score is like 23 lvls right now). 

Voxel characters allow for a gameplay with no HP mechanics. You die when your head/torso is destroyed, or both legs or if you lose the ability to attack. I used to think both arms counted but if you have flamebreath you can actually continue with out arms. Once I cleared a level with only one leg left by hopping around and breathing fire on enemies. 

Good soundtrack. All voices are text to speech, but good text to speech that is funny to listen to. As such anyone can create custom dialogue for the game. 

There is MP, I have not tried it. Duels are private lobbies only for example. 

Basically infinite replay value. Amazing game play. Unique.. there is nothing light it really that I have played before. Art style that will always look good. Amazing price range. I actually bought two copies but the guy I gave it to found it too hard. His son likes it though, but would feel weird playing with some internet friends son who I have never met. So I'll probably pick up another copy for someone else at somepoint. That's the good thing about its pricing, I could happily buy this game 4 times and not feel ripped off.

Commentatron

Commentatron is one of the robots in the duo that makes up the commentators. Only the top half of his torso is visible, as he is behind a table. He has a deep, dark voice. He is a robot with a rather large chest, resembling a muscular man. He has a black suit, headset, red eyes, and reddish hair accessories. As his name suggests, he will usually make comments on what the player is doing and what the outcome of the level was. He will often wave his arms around while speaking, and is notably more expressive than Analysis-bot, he views the user and watches him burn
In one of his lines, Commentatron asks Analysis-bot what his relationship with Purple Shep is, referencing the fact that Analysis-bot uses the same voice as Purple Shep.
In another one of his lines, Commentatron says that he loves the smell of energy swords in the morning, revealing that he has a "nose" installed.
In one of his lines, Commentatron proposed the idea that he and Analysis-bot should form a band (although he calls it a "popular musical act" due to robot speech patterns).
If you use the camera, you can see that he has legs, and has been standing up the whole time. His legs seem thin and awkward when compared to the rest of his body.
He appears to be a re-purposed mark 2 sword robot, or some sort of sword robot, presumed by his body shape.
In chapter 4, he can be seen when the human diplomat is sent to the arena to "negotiate."

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Analysis-bot

"Soon all the humans will be garbage!"

Analysis-bot is one of the robots in the duo that make up the commentators. Due to his small size, he sits on the table that Commentatron stands behind. He has no limbs at all, black coat, green eyes and accessories, and as the name suggests, he will often analyze what the player is doing and the upcoming level, occasionally answering questions from Commentatron.
In the ending cutscene of chapter 3, we get a look inside one of the Harvester Fleet ships. Inside, we see what appears to be a command center, with four robots that are the same model as Analysis-bot, just with military uniforms and different eye pieces. In chapter 4, they are revealed to be ship officers, specifically Logistics, Warfare, Mind Space, and Infantry.
In one line, Commentatron asks Analysis-bot about his relationship with Purple Shep. Analysis-bot quickly responds with "I don't know Purple Shep! We are not best friends!”
However, in another line, when Commentatron asks him about Purple Shep, he replies that they share the same voice modulator.
During the Random upgrade challenge, he mentions that if he had arms, he would like them to be the same as Upgrade bot's.
The Harvester ship officers had emergency combat modes, which included flight, flamethrowers, shooting arrows from their mouths, charging at the player, and sword wielding (although they needed to use their mouths to do so). It is unknown if Analysis Bot has these abilities as well.
In Chapter 4, Analysis-bot can be briefly seen when the human diplomat is sent to the arena to "negotiate."
Analysis-bot is apparently a big fan of Spider-Tron 5000 and Spider-Tron 6000. In one quote he says that "[he] likes robots that analyse things!
In multiple lines during story and endless mode, we are shown that Analysis-bot displays an interest in poetry. Some of his lines follow some sort of rhyme scheme, usually followed by commentatron applauding his poetic abilities.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Commentators

The Commentators are a duo of robots who add colorful comments (Red being Commentration bot and Green being Analysis bot) before and after each battle. They do not comment during battle unless a Spidertron gets cut by a saw blade or the player hits their booth. The Commentators give information on the upcoming level and make remarks about the chosen upgrades. These are often humorous, sarcastic, or even rude. The commentators are displayed on screens on each wall of the arena, and on four screens in the upgrade area. If the player manages to get up to their booth in the arena, a force field will blast the player back. The Commentators cannot be harmed. Their true thoughts on the player is unknown, as they appear to want to see the player die at one point, and at other points, they appear to favor the player. I can go on and on about this, but it's time I cut to the point.

Clone Drone in the Danger Zone (CDDZ) is a side-splitting, rib-tickling, robo-romp that'll leave you in stitches! Let's start with 3 pros and 1 con that sum up this comedic chaos.

Pro #1: The game's hilariously absurd premise has you controlling robot clones, slicing and dicing through arenas like a tin-can samurai on a caffeine high. It's the perfect blend of futuristic mayhem and slapstick humor.

Pro #2: With razor-sharp wit, the game's commentators deliver punchlines with the precision of a laser-guided sword. You'll be laughing so hard, you'll hardly notice your own gruesome, dismembered limbs scattered across the arena floor.

Pro #3: CDDZ's challenging gameplay is the cherry on top of this humor sundae, adding a sense of accomplishment to your metallic massacre. Surviving each wave of enemies feels like a well-earned badge of honor (or a really twisted joke).

Con #1: The only downside? You might end up with an uncontrollable urge to punt your Roomba across the living room after playing.

In conclusion, Clone Drone in the Danger Zone is a gut-busting, laugh-a-minute adventure that combines the best of robot combat, witty banter, and a difficulty curve that'll keep you coming back for more. Just remember to give your household appliances a reassuring pat after each gaming session.

There's upgrades for each level you complete and it gets harder through different categories of levels. there's: bronze, silver, gold, diamond, titanium, uranium and then insanium. Clone Drone in The Danger Zone is a pretty solid game where you play as [b]John Drone[/b]*, a human who has since been turned into a robot for gladiatorial entertainment by other, morally impaired robots.  Your goal is simple; Survive the arena's dangers, and maybe overthrow an evil robotic emperor while you're at it.  Or just that first one.  The plot's lightweight, and outright nonexistent in some areas, and with a game like this, it's relatively okay.  There is a Story Mode that tells a tale of resistance, and the story, while light-weight and offering a simple series of justifications for the enemy gauntlets it hurls you into, also does a great job of introducing new mechanics and weaponry in a rather natural way.
[spoiler]*Clone's name may not be John Drone[/spoiler]

Graphically, this game uses volumetric pixels, or voxels if you're not an [b]utter snob who uses fancy words.[/b]  This means 'Minecraft looks' for those who need further help, and it lends the game a blocky look that only needed a few particle effects to truly shine among the competition in that space.  Obviously, it's very readable at a glance, and with how the game plays, that's important.

Gameplay is semi-simple.  You can wield up to four weapons, a sword, a hammer, a bow, and a spear with shield.  Your goal?  Kill everything else without dying in the process.  Combat controls are simple; Swords and hammers swing where you're moving, or default to a vertical swing if you're still; Bows shoot where you're aiming, spears stab forwards at all times.  You have a dash, a jump, and with upgrades, a kick.  The game's enemies are many, varied, and vast, and all can call for different means of taking them on.  The game balances all it's weapons with strengths and disadvantages, too; While you can go [i]'pew pew'[/i] and kill stuff that way, some robots can deflect arrows.  While your hammer can certainly bonk those guys aside, now you're being shot full of holes by bow-wielding enemies.  While your sword can deflect that, it's range is too short and you are now at risk of receiving the [b]forever bonk[/b] from MC Hammerlots over there.  And while your spear has minced Hammerlots' head, his fifteen friends are now out for your oil.  So on, so forth.  Multiplayer is present and fun, too; Duels, a battle royale that's actually good, and co-operative play all round off an otherwise solid experience, and it's arguably the best part of CDiTDZ.

In terms of performance, this game runs smoothly, but be aware that voxels are anything but lightweight; This game can be a bit taxing on CPUs and GPUs alike in terms of temperature, so make sure your stuff's relatively flame-resistant before going in.  Otherwise, my CPU held a perfectly stable frame rate, save for multiplayer, where server lag becomes everybody's worst enemy, alongside the raptors that fires lasers from their faces.

While the game's story mode is relatively short, a surprisingly addicting Endless mode, several single and multiplayer challenges, and the multiplayer itself make Clone Drone rather replayable, and it supports Workshop levels in case you get tired of the game's stock levels and want to mix things up, from simply adding new arena layouts, to outright adventure maps that go beyond the arena's bounds to create long gauntlets of foes for you to die horribly to.

All told, it's a solid indie package that offers a fun time, and while it's no GoTY contender, Clone Drone is a deliciously delightful time that I can solidly recommend.  [u]Get it at MSRP, you won't be disappointed.[/u]

Clone Drone  in the Danger Zone is a simple indie game in which your human mind has been put inside a robot body. Two chad commentators known as "Commentatron" and "Analysis Bot" will make intellectual remarks during your time in the arena, in which there are a variety of different maps and a variety of different enemies can spawn. 

These enemies will typically wield: swords, bows, hammers, and spears (sometimes with shields), and they come in Marks I to V, getting harder to defeat each time. However there are some with jetpacks, some that look like they're lawyers (business bots), and flame/laser raptors.  
The story is a beautiful tale of human defiance, and friendship, between two humans who have escaped the gladiator arena, and  fight their way, from overseers to ship commanders, to kill the emperor of the robots, thereby setting mankind free. 

Also, there is a pretty cool multiplayer option, in which you can work together with other humans to complete challenges in the arena, or fight in a Battle Royale style game in Last Bot standing, or even have a 1v1 duel with your friend.

Clone Drone in the Danger Zone is a simple game, you simply fight robots and kill robots while trying not to die in the danger zone. From the outside your first look might be "this game looks really simple and the style reminds me of Minecraft with the "blockyness", but let me tell you there is so much more to this game than it seems. The story: The story was one of the things that got me and my brother hooked to this game, the story seems so simple and the next thing you know, your in a completely different feeling game. The physics: The physics are pretty good when it comes to aiming your weapon, you see your able to cut off different limbs depending on where your looking while your swing, and if you take damage you don't die right away (sometimes) instead you can still fight while only having... lets say half of your boy, one arm, 2 knees, half a head gone, its pretty astounding really. Online mode and Extras: once your done with the base game there are still a lot of things you can do like for example fight together or against other players. The game gives your challenges in order to unlock trophies, upgrades, or skins if your playing online. There's also an endless mode where you have to keep fighting and see how far you can go. This game seems so simple and it... kinda is, but if you can find the true beauty of this game, you will love it.

I do NOT recommend buying this game in any way, shape or form if you care about achievements. Since there’s already been a ton of reviews about the game in general; I will just focus on the things that pissed me off while I was trying to 100% the game so you can decide for your self if you wanna get the game. If you don’t I don’t really recommend getting it at full price either, wait for a discount.

I have spent too much f****** time & stress getting all the achievements of the game and I do NOT recommend you do the same.

Number 1) EXTREME artificial difficulty on insane

For a mental representation of how bad this game is on insane (the only achievement granting campaign mode difficulty) think about iron keep from dark souls 2, bad right? Now multiply the knights inside of it by 10 and make it a 1 hit kill (usually) with no way to heal even if they don’t kill you immediately – which usually cripples your ability to fight and leaves your death dragged out.

While I understand that it’s supposed to be a really hard difficulty, they should have implemented it in a far different way such as having more enemies than *usual* but not to the extreme level that the current version of the game has alongside making them higher MK versions of themselves so its actually challenging in a way that can be reasonably countered verses being quite literally swarmed with an impossible amount of enemies to the point where you need to kite them around traps until they reach a fair number.

You know its bad when 99% of the enemies die to friendly fire because there’s too many. It literally is RNG on if you die most of the time because of this unless I’m missing something.

2) MP Lag

Like seriously, I have NOT got a bad connection – I have 30ms on most games and I basically never have issues with any game except this one. Like it’s really bad, my character will just die for no reason some times and its genuinely infuriating considering a good half of the achievements are multiplayer. I have lagged in a lobby with only me in it for some godforsaken reason.

3) Dead MP & Sweats (ish)

Despite half of the achievements being MP based, basically all the modes are dead (this is especially potent for LBS, the pvp mode) as there’s like 300 people playing on a good day which is bad for obvious reasons. And when you DO get a game in the LBS mode its probably going to be some Russian with 500 wins so its not looking good from the start – I somehow scraped it but others might not be so lucky.

Good luck getting to Insanium if you decide to do the coop challenges solo as sometimes you just can’t find anyone, since you only get 3 retries. 

4) Challenges being repeated

On the subject of these challenges, they are literally identical down to a T as the solo versions, what’s the point? Its just making it more grindy for 0 reason.

5) Nonsensical achievement decisions

I despise, despise, despise the fact that the devs made us have to go play coop to get the coop insanium achievement if we have already done it multiple times over for the challenges. Alongside this, they straight up made it so you can’t progress the kill challenges on workshop maps for some godforsaken reason (“we did it to stop people cheesing it!” is not a valid reason since they can just use SAM). 

Finally, WHY is there an achievement tied to the devs streaming??? That’s terrible for obvious reasons.

6) Spyware

Apparently the devs put red shell spyware in this game and have it in their TOS that they can install spyware on your computer whenever they want so id be a bit cautious regardless of if its true or not.

I think this is my first review on steam, I remember watching videos when this game first released. I instantly realized it was different from other games and I got it. I don't remember why but I didn't play it myself for a bit, but when I did I could not put it down. It is a great game, if you don't believe me and want to know more you can add me and talk to me about concerns on this game. Back when multiplayer, the fire update, story modes conclusion, zombie robots, the hammer, spear, and laser... I could go on but basically before all of that, the game was still addictive and crazy fun. There were some things I got frustrated at but overall it is a very well done game that I hope continues to stay alive and updated because every now and then I come back to it to get some nostalgia. Below I will list some good things I remember and bad things I remember.

Good things:
-The PvP system is balanced and new players can take down very skilled players.
-There is a way to limit use of powerful powers such as fire breath and lasers in the form of energy consumption.
-A very different system where you can lose limbs and parts of your body making the remaining enemies harder to kill before you can repair yourself increasing the stakes.
-The stakes are always high, if you die, you could lose a clone, which you will find are limited. If you die without a clone, you have to start over.
-Before you can unlock game changing powers, you have to complete challenges to test whether you deserve them.
-AI can be strong and give a real battle.
-Players can win even in a PvP setting even if the opponent has the clear advantage. 
-Emotes exist.
-Players are very chill and offer help with multiplayer and achievements often.

Bad things:
-Limited maps and enemies, there aren't as many maps as there should be. The enemies can be hard to fight, but after a while veterans can take out rooms of the hardest enemies with there eyes closed.
-Not many weapons and powers, not much to say here. There could be a more advanced skill tree and weapons.
-Cross teaming was a big problem, I'm not sure if it still is but I can say without a doubt that there will always be a teams in PvP
-The bosses, to put it simply, are not very entertaining or interesting. The final boss is in my personal opinion the only boss fight that was somewhat difficult. All the other bosses were either just swarms of robots that you could fight rather easily, or a spider or robot with spider legs that had a very simple kiting pattern, or a set of four robots that when fought alone become easy but when fought together are the stuff of nightmares.
-Lobbies are either very full or not full at all. 
-You can see peoples wins PvP, so everyone knows your everyone's skill level making it very predictable who to fight and who to avoid. 

There are many other things but I can't remember them well enough to give an honest review of them such as the level editor, the maps, the controls, etc. Overall a very good game I found worth the price and that I can say without a doubt is what got me into video games.

This game is incredible, the amount off effort put into this game is amazing.

The weapons and upgrades. The way that this game has made its upgrades is fantastic, the weapons are unique and all feel like they have a use that no other weapon fits. Each weapon has its upsides and downsides, some weapons have some overlapping  upsides and downsides and can fill a similar purpose so it doesn't force you to get a certain weapon to deal with something and it is always possible to do it with another weapon.

The levels and maps. This is my personal favourite thing about this game, every map and levels play differently to the last, the layout of each map is different from the one before and even if a map is reused the level will still feel different from the unique set of enemies. Every map has different ways to deal with it from jet packing with a hammer to sniping with a bow.

The multiplayer modes. The multiplayer in this game is great, the connection is always smooth and doesn't feel janky. The modes from co-op to duels to ffa, they all feel like they fit and weren't just forced into the game for more content.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone who has some friends who has some money to burn and time as well, you can just chill with the bois and have a good time.
